deck.name: Land Navigation
deck.description: TC 3-25.26 - Map reading, terrain association, compass use, and grid coordinates

cards.front: What is the standard military map scale for tactical operations?
cards.back:
1:50,000 (one inch equals approximately 0.8 miles).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-2)

cards.front: On a 1:50,000 map, how large is one grid square?
cards.back:
1,000 meters × 1,000 meters (1 kilometer).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-3)

cards.front: What does the color BLACK represent on a military map?
cards.back:
Man-made features (buildings, roads, boundaries, labels).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-8)

cards.front: What does the color BLUE represent on a military map?
cards.back:
Water features (lakes, rivers, streams, swamps).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-8)

cards.front: What does the color BROWN represent on a military map?
cards.back:
Contour lines and elevation.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-8)

cards.front: What does the color GREEN represent on a military map?
cards.back:
Vegetation (woods, orchards, vineyards).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-8)

cards.front: What does the color RED represent on a military map?
cards.back:
Major roads, built-up areas, and special features.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-8)

cards.front: What is a contour line?
cards.back:
A line on a map connecting points of equal elevation.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-2)

cards.front: What is a contour interval?
cards.back:
The vertical distance between adjacent contour lines (found in marginal information).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-3)

cards.front: How do you identify a HILL on a map?
cards.back:
Contour lines forming closed circles. Elevation increases toward the center.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: How do you identify a VALLEY on a map?
cards.back:
Contour lines forming a U or V shape pointing UPHILL (toward higher elevation).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: How do you identify a RIDGE on a map?
cards.back:
Contour lines forming a U or V shape pointing DOWNHILL (toward lower elevation).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: How do you identify a SADDLE on a map?
cards.back:
Low point between two higher elevations, like an hourglass shape.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: How do you identify a DEPRESSION on a map?
cards.back:
Closed contour lines with tick marks pointing INWARD (toward lower center).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: What does steep terrain look like on a map?
cards.back:
Contour lines close together.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-6)

cards.front: What does gentle terrain look like on a map?
cards.back:
Contour lines far apart.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-6)

cards.front: What is a DRAW on a map?
cards.back:
A less developed valley, usually the beginning of a stream. Contour lines form U pointing uphill.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-9)

cards.front: What is a SPUR on a map?
cards.back:
A short ridge extending from higher ground. Contour lines form U pointing downhill.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-9)

cards.front: What is a CLIFF on a map?
cards.back:
Contour lines very close together or touching (vertical or near-vertical terrain).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-9)

cards.front: How do you read a grid coordinate? (right/up)
cards.back:
Read RIGHT first (easting), then UP (northing). Memory aid: "Right Up."

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-5)

cards.front: What is a 4-digit grid coordinate?
cards.back:
Locates to within 1,000 meters. Example: 1234 (grid square).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-6)

cards.front: What is a 6-digit grid coordinate?
cards.back:
Locates to within 100 meters. Example: 123456.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-6)

cards.front: What is an 8-digit grid coordinate?
cards.back:
Locates to within 10 meters. Example: 12345678.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-6)

cards.front: What is a 10-digit grid coordinate?
cards.back:
Locates to within 1 meter. Example: 1234567890.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-6)

cards.front: What are the three norths on a military map?
cards.back:
True North (star symbol), Grid North (GN), and Magnetic North (half arrow).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-2)

cards.front: What is declination?
cards.back:
The angular difference between magnetic north and true north at a given location.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-3)

cards.front: What is the G-M angle?
cards.back:
The angular difference between grid north and magnetic north (used for converting azimuths).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-4)

cards.front: How do you convert magnetic azimuth to grid azimuth when G-M angle is EAST?
cards.back:
SUBTRACT the G-M angle from the magnetic azimuth.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-5)

cards.front: How do you convert magnetic azimuth to grid azimuth when G-M angle is WEST?
cards.back:
ADD the G-M angle to the magnetic azimuth.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-5)

cards.front: What is the memory aid for declination conversion?
cards.back:
"East is Least, West is Best" - subtract for east, add for west.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-5)

cards.front: What is an azimuth?
cards.back:
A horizontal angle measured clockwise from a north base line (0-360 degrees or 0-6400 mils).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-1)

cards.front: How do you calculate a back azimuth?
cards.back:
If azimuth <180°: ADD 180. If azimuth ≥180°: SUBTRACT 180.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-8)

cards.front: What are the three methods of holding a compass?
cards.back:
Compass-to-Cheek, Center-Hold, and Compass-to-Map.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 9, para 9-3)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the bezel ring on the lensatic compass?
cards.back:
Allows you to set and hold a desired azimuth for navigation.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 9, para 9-2)

cards.front: What is a pace count?
cards.back:
The number of double-steps (counting each time one foot hits the ground) to travel 100 meters.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-4)

cards.front: What is dead reckoning?
cards.back:
Navigation using azimuth and distance from a known point without terrain association.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-2)

cards.front: What is terrain association?
cards.back:
Navigation by comparing map features to ground features you observe.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-3)

cards.front: What is intersection?
cards.back:
Locating an unknown point by sighting from two or more known positions.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 7, para 7-2)

cards.front: What is resection?
cards.back:
Determining your unknown location by sighting to two or more known points.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 7, para 7-3)

cards.front: What is a handrail in land navigation?
cards.back:
A linear feature (road, stream, ridge) paralleling your route that helps guide movement.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-8)

cards.front: What is a catching feature?
cards.back:
An obvious terrain feature beyond your objective that tells you you've gone too far.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-9)

cards.front: What is a steering mark?
cards.back:
A distant object (tree, hill, tower) on your azimuth used to maintain direction.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-10)

cards.front: What is deliberate offset?
cards.back:
Intentionally navigating slightly left or right of the objective to know which way to turn upon reaching a linear feature.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-11)

cards.front: How many mils are in a circle?
cards.back:
6,400 mils (military) or 6,283 mils (scientific).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-1)

cards.front: How many degrees are in one mil (approximate)?
cards.back:
1 mil ≈ 0.056 degrees. Or: 17.78 mils ≈ 1 degree.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-1)
